docs.text: Projectile Motion Explorer body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; margin: 40px; line-height: 1.6; background-color: #f9f9f9; color: #333; } h1, h2 { color: #2c3e50; } #plot { width: 100%; max-width: 800px; margin: auto; } .section { margin-bottom: 50px; } Projectile Range vs. Angle 1. Theoretical Foundation Projectile motion describes the curved path an object follows when launched at an angle. Ignoring air resistance, the range of a projectile is given by the formula: R = (v₀² * sin(2θ)) / g Where: v₀ : Initial velocity θ : Launch angle g : Gravitational acceleration (9.81 m/s²) 2. Simulation Initial Velocity (m/s): 30 m/s 3. Practical Insights The range is maximum at a 45° angle for flat ground and no air resistance. You can explore how different velocities affect the shape and peak of the curve. Real-world adjustments may include: Initial height offset Air resistance (drag) Uneven terrain function computeRange(v0, g, angleDeg) { const angleRad = angleDeg * Math.PI / 180; return (Math.pow(v0, 2) * Math.sin(2 * angleRad)) / g; } function updatePlot() { const g = 9.81; const v0 = parseFloat(document.getElementById('velocity').value); document.getElementById('velocityValue').textContent = v0; const angles = []; const ranges = []; for (let theta = 0; theta <= 90; theta += 0.5) { angles.push(theta); ranges.push(computeRange(v0, g, theta)); } const trace = { x: angles, y: ranges, type: 'scatter', mode: 'lines', line: { color: 'royalblue' }, name: `v₀ = ${v0} m/s` }; const layout = { title: 'Range vs Angle of Projection', xaxis: { title: 'Angle (degrees)' }, yaxis: { title: 'Range (meters)' } }; Plotly.newPlot('plot', [trace], layout); } updatePlot(); // initial plot
